abstracts.cdata!:
The Pilot Fishery Development Project
            has the main objectives of improving the operation and
            management of fishing ports, introducing an effective
            institutional framework for community-driven co-management
            of marine resources, and restoring the country's
            previous capacity in aquaculture as well as exploring the
            potential for further development of aquaculture,
            particularly for high value species. To achieve these aims,
            the project supports three main components. The first
            component rehabilitates fishing port facilities and supports
            the institutional strengthening of Fishery Management
            Organizations to improve their management of fishing port
            facilities, and to promote self-regulation as the key to
            sustainable marine resource management. To that end, the
            project recruits national coordiantors and regional
            promoters, supplies international technical assistance to
            the FMOs, prepares fishery management plans, develops marine
            ecotourism, and supports training and demonstration
            programs. The second component provides support to restock
            carp in reservoirs, supports the Koran restocking program,
            and pilots a program to test the aquaculture of new marine
            and fresh water species such as tilapia and shrimp. The
            third component finances legal training and assistance for
            preparing technical documents, provides legal assitance to
            support the Fisheries Directorate, supports a fisheries
            management information system, and prepares a business plan
            for the Fishery Research Institute.
